advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> APPLE LOGO (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Apple Logo was a very successful implementation of Logo. It contained some advanced features such as property list and packages, as well as extremely good documentation.<br><br> At the time, Apple thought the Logo language would encourage schools to invest heavily in personal computers for all the class levels.<br> Sadly, Logo never became the revolutionary language that they had hoped for and very few schools taught it to their pupils (except in France).</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>German advert for the Philips Odyssey 200 model.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.dieterkoenig.at/ccc/" target="_blank">Dieter Koening</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Gazelle was a huge computer compared to the personal computer sizes of the time, so large that it has casters on the cabinet for moving it!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"128k=2000f<br> Better know it before buying a 64k"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The memo from the company president:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Your purchase request for six personal computers just reached my desk.<br><br> What gives?<br><br> I thought you understood our grouth plans, Jack, but the computers you have recommanded are dead ends. They might do the job today, but what about tomorrow? They don't connect together to form any kind of functional system. The 8 bits aren't compatible with the 16 bits models. And I doubt the software that run on the computers you want will be of any use later when we're forced to buy computers that work together.<br><br> You saved us a little now, Jack, but your decision will cost us a bundle as we grow into the future. We are growing, Jack, and I'm sure that you want to be part of the growth.<br><br> See me before you go home tonight.<br> Tom<br><br></font> Cheer up Jack!<br><br> Now the advert:<br><br><font color="#666666"> If you don't want your boss to limit you growth, don't limit the growth of the company. Consider small business computers that can keep up with your business by giving you options for expansion in the future.<br> With Televideo Systems Inc. you get what no other small business computer can offer...</font><br><br> Perhaps jack was right...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FLYER - PAGE 2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.peekandpoke.org" target="_blank">www.peekandpoke.org</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR AD #3 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this advert, Victor tried to convince future IBM PC buyers that the Victor 9000 hardware technology was much more advanced than that of its competitor. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DEMO TAPE INLAY #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.primo.homeserver.hu/" target="_blank">PRIMO home-page</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to chrism3667 for the picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Thank you boss !" <br><br> The ad incite employees to ask their boss to buy these Apricot systems...clever.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE - HAPPY COUPLE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.retrorene.nl/" target="_blank">Retro Rene's Gaming Corner</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

computer.colors: 16 (8 colours in normal or bright modes)
computer.description:
The HC-91 is a Romanian ZX-Spectrum clone. Two versions of the HC-91 computer were manufactured by Ice-Felix.
The first one used the same case and the same keyboard as the HC-85 with coloured keys for only external difference. This version was also sold with the HC-90 name. The second one featured a new 50 keys keyboard design (picture). Thanks to two small rectractable feet, the keyboard can be tilted.
Also, the motherboard was completely redrawn to take account of the new memory chips (only two 4464 memory chips was needed instead of 24 chips in the HC-85 version). No additional feature was added and the systems were always pure Sinclair Spectrum clones, but also CP/M compatible machines if a disk extension was used.
Despite the use of many components from Eastern Europe, one finds however several Japanese, American and even Brasilian chips.
An HC-91+ was also produced, it featured a daughter board with three interfaces: 5,25" floppy disk drives, serial RS232 and local network. (See the Read More section for more details)
production of HC-91 was stoped in 1992, when Ice-Felix lunched the HC-2000, which had same basic features as the hc-91 plus built-in floppy disc drive, and hardware upgrades.
The last HC model was a 386SX PC compatible with 1 MB ram, vga, buit-in 3.5 floppy, apox. same case as HC2000 and TV and monitor conectors. An optional 40-100 MB hard disk could be added. The computer was available a year or two and it didn't sold very well.
computer.keyboard: Mechanical 40 or 50 keys (EDIT, TAB, CAPS LOCK, CAPS SHIFT, EXT MODE, DELETE, RETURN, GRAPH, SYMBOL SHIFT, arrow keys)
computer.name: HC-91
computer.ports: Tape recorder (DIN5), expansion bus, joystick (DB9), power in, RGB (DB9), TV aerial video output (cinch)
computer.power: External AC adaptor. Built-in power regulation

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> 40-KEY VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>The HC-91 40 (colored) keys version. <br><br> HC-91 uses 40 mechanical keys. That is the main weakness of the microcomputer (after long periods of inactivity, keys need to be "formed" because of oxidation). </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> THE MOTHERBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>The system needs 46 chips instead of 80 in the HC-85 version.<br><br> The HC-91 computer have 2 X 4464 DRAMS (64K X 4 bit each), and a strange video sequencer with discrete IC's. This sequencer runs synchronous with the CPU clock, at the exact time when CPU don't access the "video" area. There was no special video RAM IC's, and no wait states or CPU clock blocking. <br><br> The main board have all hardware support for CP/M, including a system BIOS, with the exception of the disk controller. The CP/M use 56 KB of RAM plus 8 KB video logic bank <br><br> Mainboard provides 64 holes <b>(6)</b> for specific EXTENSION BOARD, wich can be mounted at bottom. A 64 or 96 female connector can be used on the computer, the extension has the male connector.<br> Some variants have been produced with extension incorporated. In this variants, the bottom connector was doubled, in the middle (mainboard-extension, with rectangular hole for 64-pin connector). In this way, standard HC-EXTENSION's could be home-mounted by hobbysts <br><br> <b>(1)</b> TV Aerial UHF modulator<br> <b>(2)</b> Video RGB out DB9 plug<br> <b>(3)</b> Power plug. An external AC adaptor supply the power<br> <b>(4)</b> Joystick DB9 connector<br> <b>(5)</b> Microprocessor Z80-A East-European version<br> <b>(6)</b> Extension board holes<br> <b>(7)</b> 16 KB ROM chip holding the Spectrum BASIC interpreter<br> <b>(8)</b> Two 4464 chips (64K x 4 bits) holding 64 KB of RAM<br> <b>(9)</b> Tape recorder DIN plug</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHIPS CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>Note the East-European Z80 microprocessor beside a Japanese 16 BK Eprom. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHIPS CLOSE-UP #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Many east-European chips (Kxx series) in this board area</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE THE CASE COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Keyboard back side<br> Voltage regulator and its cooler<br> Loudspeaker.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR CONNECTORS</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Tape recorder DIN plug. Input from TAPE has an AO amplifier without negative reaction for TTL signal formatting. Output has only a resistive divider from output port pin. <br> <b>(2)</b> 54-pin connector for external extension. The pinouts are Spectrum compatible at CPU lines, but there are significant differences for other lines<br> <b>(3)</b> DB9-Male, input from joystick, mapped directly to the numerical keys<br> <b>(4)</b> Power plug. An external AC adaptor supplies the powerpower supply. HC has an internal power regulator LM 323 (5V/3A)wich produces 5VCC. Boards with ALS needs aprox 0.7 Amps at 5V, without extension. <br> <b>(5)</b> DB9-Female, output for RGB monitors with intensification, TTL compatible<br> <b>(6)</b> Output from TV modulator, PAL encoded using an PROM and SCLK:4 (system clock divided by 4)<br> <b>(7)</b> Reset switch (beside the keyboard on the 40-key version)<br> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> HC-91+</strong></font><br><blockquote>See information about the HC-91+ in the "More information" section.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Grecu Cristi</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> HC-91+ EXPANSION CARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>IF-1 expansion card connectors, from left to right:<br><br> • Two jacks for local network.<br> • DB9 serial RS232C connector<br> • FDD connector<br> • Expansion bus connector<br> • Power supply connector. If the card is not powered or connected, the computer still works like an ordinary HC-91.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to </b>Grecu Cristi</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPLETE SYSTEM</strong></font><br><blockquote>HC-91 with extension board and additional case. This special system was 'home made' by Daniel Ioan from various parts available at ICE factory.<br><br> <b>(1)</b> Handmade NMI button (No Maskable Interrupt)<br> <b>(2)</b> Tape recorder DIN plug<br> <b>(3)</b> Extension connector 2 from extension board<br> <b>(4)</b> Extension connector 1 from computer board<br> <b>(5)</b> Handmade Parallel port, not Centronics compatible<br> <b>(6)</b> Joystick connector<br> <b>(7)</b> Floppy disc connector (extension board)<br> <b>(8)</b> Power supply connector<br> <b>(9)</b> Serial interface<br> <b>(10)</b> RGB TTL video output<br> <b>(11)</b> Network jacks<br> <b>(12)</b> TV/RF modulator<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Daniel IOAN for picture and explanations</p></blockquote>
